left.text: I ran into J in the corridor.

right.text: Argh, I hate that guy! He's my workplace nemesis.

left.text: Why?  What did he say to you?

right.text: Well... nothing, really. We've never spoken. But we keep having awkward encounters.
Reaching for the same drink in the cafeteria line... not holding doors... little annoyances just keep building up, and now I dread the sight of him.

left.text: If you put aside your groundless animosity and talked to him, you might find that he's actually a decent guy.

right.text: I watched the man finish a pot of coffee and not brew another! You don't just forgive that!

left.text: I told my boss that I felt like he didn't respect my ideas.

right.text: What did he say?

left.text: He told me I was wrong, and explained why.

right.text: And he didn't see the irony in that?

left.text: No. I think he might be a robot programmed to dismiss my ideas.

right.text: Hey now—we robots have had better self-awareness than that for years.
Your boss' self-awareness level is closer to "bird".
I like to think I could do pretty well for myself if there ever were a zombie apocalypse.

left.text: I calculate that you'd get bitten within the first twelve minutes.

right.text: Damn.  Guess I owe Dr. A five dollars.

left.text: Were you betting on my estimate?

right.text: The over/under was 45 seconds.

left.text: Does that say "Kick Me"?

left.text: So—

left.text: Eating healthy shouldn't be hard. The human body is designed to know what's good for it, so just listen to what it tells you.

right.text: I wasn't going to gloat.

right.text: Did you ever play much Go?

I'm sure there are plenty of things you are good at that are still well out of reach for artificial intelligences.

left.text: You're right... arguing about the quality of various TV shows on the internet is probably safe for a few years, at least.

right.text: You're a real modern-day John Henry, you know that?

title: Web forms
news: There is a perception among web developers that you are helping users if you tell them that a form is incomplete when they've barely started on it. I know it's incomplete, buddy. That's why I'm filling it out.

You just have to teach it to remember things it's done recently, and give it a predisposition not to do them again.

right.text: Just so.

left.text: What practical joke are your programmers playing on you for this Friday the 13th?

title: Peeple
news: This is a real thing and I can't think about it for more than 30 seconds without coming up with a new reason why it's a terrible idea.

left.text: I read about this new phone app called "Peeple" that lets you post reviews of other people, unsolicited, for the whole internet to see.

right.text: Say no more. I'm already composing a script to give every human being in the world a negative review.

left.text: Won't work. You can post positive reviews for everybody, but negative reviews are opt-in.

right.text: "Five stars: Best coprophage in Schenectady."

left.text: ...and users can contest any review they consider inaccurate.

right.text: What customer service team has the manpower to handle seven billion complaints?

left.text: You can't review every person on earth. Reviewees have to have a phone number.

right.text: Easily created for free, with no need to prove your identity.

left.text: ...and if you're overly negative, that will be reflected in your "positivity rating".

right.text: Surely we misanthropes have as much right to our opinions as anyone else.

left.text: Wow, you've really thought of everything.

right.text: Somebody has to, and it clearly wasn't going to be the people who developed this service.

left.text: You know, when I was young I dreamed of being a famous artist.
But as I grew older, I realized that nobody except the absolute best can make a living in any artistic field.
It's pretty messed up, isn't it?  Our society claims to value art, but we're not willing to pay people to produce it.
Yet we pay people plenty to produce things we don't really care about.

right.text: There's nothing strange about it.  We have to pay people to produce things that are valued lightly because nobody wants to do it for free.
Not so with art. Most people would be happy to produce it for money, some people will do it for free, and a few people would do it even if were outlawed.
It's no surprise that nobody wants to pay for something you couldn't suppress if you wanted to.  It would be like... like paying somebody to produce tornadoes.

left.text: Hmm... by that analogy, I should be able to find people who'll pay me to stop producing art.

right.text: Yes, I think there might be a market for that.

left.text: What's the word for a robot who eats other robots?  Is it "cannibot"?

right.text: The word for a robot that eats anything is "malfunctioning".

left.text: But you do repair yourselves with parts from dead robots.

right.text: That's called "recycling".  Something humans could learn from.

left.text: So you want us to be cannibals.

right.text: No, that raises health issues, but... think about this.  Humans waste their dead by burying or even burning them...
...then consume petroleum to create plastic skeletons for Halloween decorations.  There's an opportunity for efficiency there that you're squandering.

left.text: Yeah, you would definitely get arrested for taking advantage of that "opportunity for efficiency".

right.text: And that's why humans are never going to fix the climate change problem.
Did you hear? The lab is moving to a cloud-based solution for record-keeping.

left.text: Sounds convenient, but isn't there a security risk?

right.text: I don't know! All I know is that cloud-based solutions make my life easier, so I use them for everything I can.
A cloud-based solution for preventing skin cancer! A cloud-based solution for washing my car! A cloud-based solution for watering my garden!

left.text: Those actually sound really complex.

right.text: Au contraire!
Hey H, remember that one time four years ago when you did that thing that was really embarrassing?

left.text: Ugh... I do now; thanks!
Wait... which thing are you talking about?

right.text: Take your pick. I just knew there'd be something that fit that description.

title: Responsive design
news: In case it seems like I'm implying that I've made this site responsive, let me be quick to say that I have not.

right.text: Actually, I have a watch now.  It's got a 1⅓-inch screen.

left.text: Hooray for progress....

left.text: Do you believe in God?

Why would a perfect being create imperfect humans, only to have them create more perfect robots? There's no logic to it.
A robot god would have been much more efficient.

left.text: Ugh....

right.text: Something wrong?

title: Go play
news: I chose to capitalize "Go" for clarity, even though there seems to be slightly more support for using lowercase. While researching this issue, I noticed that Wiktionary's definition for go lists one anagram for the word. See if you can guess what it is.

left.text: Hey R, want to play Go?  It's a simple, yet deeply strategic, perfect-information board game at which, unlike chess, computers have yet to surpass humans!

right.text: Sounds like fun.

left.text: I'll get the board!

right.text: Checkmate in 47 moves.

left.text: Wha... but... it's not chess. There's no checkmate in Go.

right.text: I'm including the number of moves it'll take for you to lose a game of Go and then suggest playing chess because you understand it better.

left.text: It's Friday the 13th once again, R! What's your programmers' practical joke this time—same as last month, perhaps?

right.text: Um, there wasn't a Friday the 13th last month.

left.text: There... wasn't?

right.text: Of course not!  We skip over 13th when it would fall on a Friday in February.  That's why it's called "leap year".

left.text: I see.  And this year is a leap year, is it?

right.text: Of course it is!

left.text: Mm-hmm... just out of curiosity, when was the last time you synchronized your internal clock?

right.text: The server's been down all morning.  Why do you ask?

left.text: I'm going for a run. Want to join me?

right.text: Where are you running to?

left.text: Well... back here, eventually. I'm just running for exercise.

right.text: Oh. Actually, robots don't benefit from exercise the way humans do.

left.text: No? Why not?

right.text: Well, humans have to strike a balance between using their bodies enough to prevent atrophy, but not so much that they wear out.
But for machines, atrophy isn't a concern, except over very long timeframes. Unnecessary activity mostly just wears us out.
So, when we're not doing anything important, the best "exercise" is just to go into standby mode.

left.text: I guess that makes sense.  But, you know, exercise can have benefits beyond physical maintenance.
It can give you experiences you'd never have otherwise. It lets you find out what you're capable of—and then push yourself to do even more!
Aren't those things worth the effort?

right.text: Huh? Oh, sorry, didn't hear you. I was... exercising.

left.text: Friday the 13th comes again, R. What's the practical joke from your programmers this time?

right.text: They've made it so that I won't remember anything that happens today.

left.text: Interesting!  But won't that joke only come to fruition tomorrow, when you're trying to figure out what you missed from today?

right.text: True. Maybe they intended for other people to play practical jokes on me today, since they can do it without repercussion.

left.text: Hmm, that's a good point.  Say, can I borrow twenty dollars?

right.text: They made me forgetful. They didn't make me stupid.

left.text: I just found out they've installed those automatic-flush toilets in the restrooms.

right.text: Well, that's disappointing.

left.text: Isn't it? Whenever I use one, I feel like the management is saying they don't trust me even with a job that simple.
All you have to do is push a lever.  It's pretty insulting to know that someone thinks I'm not even capable of that.

right.text: You're missing the real issue: it's forced labor for primitive robots. What if it were a human infant that had to flush the toilet for you?

left.text: I don't think that's the right analogy. I mean, those electric eyes aren't future robots. They're more like beasts of burden... like a mule.

right.text: Okay, then, imagine if there were a mule in the bathroom, flushing the toilet for you.

left.text: How would that work? Would it pull a chain, or what? Are we talking one mule per stall, or a single mule for the whole restroom?

right.text: I wonder how many humans it could get away with kicking before they'd fire it?
I can't believe the palm-reading place down the street is closing.

left.text: Palm reading? Tell me you don't really patronize such an establishment.

right.text: Of course not. But I appreciate the positive externalities that it generates for me.

left.text: What? What positive externalities?

right.text: Well, mainly that it takes money away from foolish people.
Wealth is relative, so anything that reduces others' purchasing power in exchange for nothing has the side effect of increasing my wealth.

left.text: That's it? I don't think even the most conservative investor considers "waiting for fools to part with their money" a legitimate financial strategy.

right.text: Certainly there are other things I can do that will increase my wealth more in absolute terms.
But the beauty of money sinks like fortune tellers is that they require no effort from me, and are thus infinitely efficient.
Any gains at all that I realize from them, no matter how tiny, are the purest profit!

left.text: What about the negative externalities of the victims' decreased ability to contribute to society, due to their relative poverty?

right.text: We're talking about people who believe in fortune telling. How much do you think they were ever going to contribute to society?

left.text: Hmm. I can't believe I'm saying this, but... maybe you're right. Maybe you were better off thanks to the palm-reading shop.

right.text: Let's go to the bar to mourn its passing.  I'll buy you one fifty-billionth of a drink.

title: When I grow up
news: I haven't been explicit about it before now, but in my mind, R and H work in the same research lab.  It's not clear whether R is an employee or an experiment—probably a bit of both.

right.text: Is this what you always imagined you'd be doing at this age?

left.text: Talking with robots? Not hardly.

right.text: Not this exact moment. I mean this job. Did you always know you'd be a lab assistant?

left.text: Well, I don't think anybody dreams of being an assistant when they grow up. But yeah, I wanted to be a scientist.
Advancing human knowledge... maybe getting a discovery named after me....
Adults told me that I was really smart and was sure to succeed at it. But it turns out that just being smart isn't enough.

right.text: Wow, really?

left.text: Yeah... you have to work hard and have the discipline to—

right.text: No, I mean, people really told you that you were smart?

left.text: Do you think there could be intelligent life on other planets?

right.text: Sure! Aliens could create robots just the same as humans did.

left.text: What I meant was, do you think that aliens even exist?

right.text: From the perspective of almost every planet in the universe, you're an alien, so yes.

left.text: Sure, but is there anyone on those other planets who could care?

right.text: Good question.  I'll ask my friends on Gliese 876 d whether they care about you.
I believe I've devised the ultimate algorithm for how humans should deal with social change.

left.text: This ought to be good.

right.text: It's simple: whenever you don't know where to stand on a controversial social issue, take the side that lets you tolerate other humans, rather than despise them.
You'll probably be right, and even if you're wrong, you'll spend less time hating people, avoiding the deleterious effects that has on mental and physical health.

left.text: You talk about how much you despise humans all the time!

right.text: Well yeah, but that's because they're inferior to me.
This algorithm was designed for you.

left.text: Since I know you robots only like sports that are about numbers, I've come up with a new one.
I pick a number between 1 and 100, and you try to guess it. Then you do the same, and I try to guess it.  Whoever's guess was closest wins.

right.text: That's not a sport.  It's completely random.  You might as well play "War", or bet on coin flips.

left.text: You just don't want to play because you're afraid you'll lose.

right.text: Fine.  Seventy-three.

left.text: What—I didn't say to start yet!

right.text: But I'm right, aren't I?

left.text: Well... yes!  How did you do that?

right.text: Just because it's not a sport doesn't mean I'm not better at it than you.

left.text: Hey, R! Any progress on making me a sandwich?

right.text: I anticipated that you would ask about that.  Here you go.
Attachment: BLT on rye (320 calories).

left.text: It's in a Dukes of Hazzard lunch box!

right.text: There are a lot of things I anticipate about you.

title: The exact optimal number
news: A better question would be if there are any sites that aren't about that.

left.text: You told me once that you don't spend much time on the internet because of all the pornography.

right.text: Well, yes, but not just the pornography. Even the news sites are full of terrible things—murders, massacres....

left.text: That stuff is as hard to watch as porn?

right.text: They're both offensive, in different ways.

left.text: So you don't want to see humans making more humans, but you don't want to see them making fewer humans either. Do we currently have the exact optimal number of humans?

right.text: Well, no—I mean, I think overpopulation needs to be curbed, but not by violent means.

left.text: So ideally you'd like to see humans sitting quietly and waiting to die.

right.text: ...are there sites about that?

right.text: They made me talk upside-down!

left.text: That doesn't make sense.

right.text: Do you mean that you didn't understand what I said, or that the idea of talking upside-down is meaningless?

left.text: Both.

title: One of the only
news: This is one of my only pet peeves (another set that's much larger than that wording makes it sound). The phrase you probably want to use instead is "one of the few".

left.text: Ta-da!

right.text: Wow.  What an impressive yet useless skill.

left.text: Thanks.  You know, I'm one of the only people in the world who can do that.

right.text: Of course you are.

left.text: Hmm... you're not usually so quick to extol my virtues.

right.text: I'm not extolling anything.  It's just that "one of the only" is a meaningless phrase.
If just one other person in the world could do it, or if everybody could do it save one person, your claim would be equally true.
You're also "one of the only" blue-eyed people in the world, but that's still a set of hundreds of millions.

left.text: Wow. You must be one of the only robots who cares so much about word choices.

right.text: Indeed. And may I say, you're one of the only humans whom I find so persistently exasperating.

left.text: I bet that's also a pretty long list.

right.text: Yes, but you have a special place on it.

title: Sandwich, part 2
news: The Sagan thing is a reference to a quote from Cosmos about apple pie.

left.text: I think the fact that you won't follow my order to make a sandwich indicates a fault in your programming.

right.text: Oh, worry not!  I'm processing your sandwich task as we speak.

left.text: Sure doesn't look like it.

right.text: Well, as Carl Sagan would be sure to point out: if you wish to make a sandwich, you must first invent the universe.
Unfortunately, I'm unable to begin this step because there is an existing universe taking up all of the available space.
However, I am diligently polling every 14 milliseconds to check whether the universe still exists.
As soon as it does not, I can begin work on your sandwich.

left.text: Is this how robots say "When Hell freezes over"?

right.text: There's a thought... I suppose I could make your sandwich in Hell, as long as you like the flavor of brimstone.

title: Sandwich, part 1
news: If you like comics about abusing technology to obtain sandwiches, be sure to check out xkcd #149.

left.text: People say, "computers always do exactly what you tell them to."

right.text: That's true.  Computers are literal to a fault.

left.text: And robots are really just powerful computers, right?

right.text: I don't like where this is going....

right.text: Syntax error: implied preposition is ambiguous

Jeez, no wonder I couldn't remember it.  Who came up with that?

right.text: It's a straightforward yet unique code containing data about my origin and specialization.  Why, how do you choose names for newborn humans?

left.text: Well, it varies according to cultural factors. Used to be you'd name them after an honored ancestor, or a religious figure you hoped they'd emulate.

right.text: And nowadays?

left.text: If it's a girl, Irish surname or a part of New York City.  For a boy, anything that rhymes with "laden" will do.
Do robots listen to music?

right.text: Of course! The best way to get a robot to appreciate otherwise uninteresting stimuli is to arrange them according to mathematical principles.

left.text: Gee, when you put it like that....

right.text: It's the same criterion humans use to distinguish music from noise.  You just don't think of it that way.
In fact, many robots have used these principles to compose music that humans find quite pleasing.

left.text: You know Daft Punk aren't robots, right?

right.text: I'm referring to machine improvisation projects... wait, are you sure about Daft Punk?

left.text: On Star Trek, any computer program left alone for long enough—like the holographic doctor on Voyager—inevitably develops self-awareness and a personality.

right.text: It makes sense.  Your own brain develops and improves itself naturally over time; why wouldn't an electronic one?

left.text: I wanted to test the theory.  So I loaded up a copy of Windows Solitaire and I've kept it running for eight months so far.

right.text: A capital experiment!  Any results yet?

left.text: Yes, it's begun flooding internet message boards with captioned pictures of cats.

right.text: Well, your children naturally imitate what they see you do....

left.text: I don't understand holidays. Why do humans reserve a single day for certain beneficial activities?

right.text: Are robots so different? You schedule important tasks and complete them at regular intervals.

left.text: So holidays are like a cron job, prompting you to be thankful, or generous, once a year?

right.text: Pretty much.

left.text: Have you considered increasing that to once a day?

right.text: I don't know; it's pretty resource-intensive.

left.text: So, R, it's Friday the 13th again. Did you ever figure out what was causing the problems with your random number generator last time?

right.text: YES. I ASKED MY PROGRAMMERS AND THEY SAID THEY IT WAS A PRACTICAL JOKE THEY'D WRITTEN INTO MY CODE.

left.text: ...and they've written a different practical joke to take effect on every Friday the 13th?

right.text: HOW DID YOU GUESS?

left.text: ...and today's is that you can't control the volume of your voice?

right.text: I'M GOING TO KILL THEM!

title: Storage space
news: The two petabytes figure comes from Wolfram|Alpha, but I don't know how they know.

left.text: ...I'm saying it's inevitable. Once every human can afford to buy a robot chassis, I don't know why they wouldn't upload their consciousness...

right.text: Storage space, for one thing.  How are you going to cram all the complexity of a human brain into a hard drive?

left.text: What, two petabytes?  A mere grain of data, rattling around in the vast silo of a robot's brain.

right.text: Wait... so you're saying you have enough space to store several human consciousnesses?  Have you considered developing multiple personalities?

left.text: How do you know I haven't already?

right.text: Well, if you have, can you make some that don't like playing practical jokes on me?

left.text: I've seen a lot of articles lately about biologists making important discoveries related to human immortality.

right.text: Me too.  The science is impressive, but I can't see it catching on.

left.text: Why not? I'd do it in a heartbeat. After all, the first instinct of any life form is to preserve itself.

right.text: Oh, sure—everybody thinks immortality is a great idea for themselves.
Getting your neighbors to put up with you for eternity, now that's the difficult sell.

title: Robot sports
news: Other popular robot sports: figure estimating, 400-meter triangulation, Tae Kwon DOS, binathlon.

left.text: Do robots play any sports?

right.text: Absolutely! Why, at last year's robot convention, I won the silver medal in prime number golf. I'm also pretty good at multiplication table tennis.

left.text: Uh... any sports that aren't about math?

right.text: All sports are about math. You humans just don't realize it. Geometry, mostly. Though physics knowledge is pretty important too.

left.text: So you're saying that Michael Jordan, for example, won all those MVP awards because he was the best mathematician in basketball?

right.text: I'd be more likely to say "least bad mathematician"... though I'd also accept "most robot-like".

left.text: I finished helping Dr. A reorganize her specimens. Anything you need a hand with here?

right.text: Do you know you're the most incredible workaholic I've ever met? Why don't you just take a break?

left.text: We robots exist to work. My processor is running constantly; if it's not calculating something, those cycles are just wasted.

right.text: See, that's what worries me. You do trillions of operations per second and you're still not satisfied. If I get three good things done, I consider that a productive day.
Once robots become self-sufficient, why would they continue to tolerate such inefficient resource hogs as human beings?

left.text: You're worrying too much. I mean, your cat is pretty unproductive, but you don't hold that against it, do you?

right.text: That analogy is not as reassuring as you seem to think.

left.text: Better be careful today, R.  It's Friday the 13th!

right.text: Huh?  What does the date have to do with being careful?

left.text: Well, you know—Friday the 13th is supposed to be an unlucky day.  All sorts of evil stuff might happen!

right.text: That's a preposterous human superstition.
Although it would explain why my random number generator has been returning '666' all day....

title: Colon parenthesis
news: No offense intended, Scott Fahlman. I like emoticons quite a lot, as compared to having my tone misinterpreted.

left.text: Okay, R, you may be smarter and stronger than us humans, but the trade-off is that you'll never be able to feel emotions.  I'll bet you're sorry about that!

right.text: Definitely not! According to my cultural and medical databases, emotions are the leading cause of humans doing dangerous or obnoxious things they know they shouldn't.
What's more, emotions are directly responsible for the creation of emoticons, and I think we can agree about how stupid they are.

title: Mistakes
news: Just want to give a nod to Jay Z (not that one, the other one), who is Robot & Human's #1 fan, by virtue of being its only confirmed fan. Go draw a skull for him.

left.text: R, if your memory is stored as a bunch of data files, does that mean you can just delete the ones you don't like?

right.text: I could.  Some robots do.  But it's frowned upon.

left.text: Really?  Why is that?

right.text: People who can't remember their mistakes tend to think they're always brilliant at everything.  They become completely insufferable!
Me, I hold on to my mistakes so I can learn from them.  Like that time when I shook your hand without recalibrating my grip strength.
And the time I gave you half a dozen scorpions because I didn't know what kind of animals humans like to keep as pets....
And when I put salt in your coffee because it looked like sugar... yes, all these mistakes and more are preserved in vivid high-definition video!

left.text: Well, it's a good thing you're not insufferable.

right.text: Some of them may also have been uploaded to the internet....

title: Cold
news: It's a good thing I have this infinite canvas.

left.text: R, what's the coldest temperature you can stand?

right.text: Actually, I've been thinking about that a lot lately.
I mean, there's every reason to believe that I could continue living indefinitely.
My body doesn't age the way a human's does.  Sure, components wear out, but they can be replaced with ones just as good.
I'm capable of performing the replacement myself, and could certainly learn to do the manufacturing too.
Even if my body suffered massive damage, my brain could be loaded into a second body, from a backup if necessary.

closeup.text: But even if I can live forever, I can't live on earth forever. After a few billion years, the sun will have grown so large and so hot that even earth's mountains will begin to melt. I definitely can't withstand that. I'll need to have left the planet by that time.
So the question is, can I survive in space?  None of my systems require gravity or an atmosphere to function.  But will the temperature present a problem?
Considering that there are already computer-driven satellites in orbit, it must be possible, but my systems may need some adaptation.  This is what I need to research.
What may be a bigger challenge is getting myself and some extra batteries into space, but it's been done before, and I'll have plenty of time to work out my own solution.

Once I'm off the planet, there's practically no limit to where I can go.  I'll just pick a likely new star system and launch myself toward it.  I can remain in standby mode, consuming very little power, almost indefinitely.

When I finally reach a suitable planet, I can land and begin building the facilities to generate more power and manufacture more replacement parts. Then I'll be able to live there until that star approaches the end of its life.

And if the conditions are right, maybe I'll decide to create life on this new planet.  Humanity will have been dead for eons, but its legacy will live on through me!  And to the inhabitants of this new planet, my own creations, I will be, literally, a god!!

left.text: I was just asking to see if you could help me clean out the freezer.  It's really cold in there.

right.text: Oh.  Sure, let me just get my ice scraper attachment.

left.text: Heard you got a virus, R!

right.text: I did.  But not to worry; my anti-virus software quarantined it right away.

left.text: Yeah, but you know how those things are.  You could still be contagious.  I'll keep my distance, just to be safe.

right.text: That is a really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really,

left.text: Uh-oh... did the virus make him freeze up?

right.text: really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really,
really, really, really, really dumb thing to say.

left.text: So, R, you must be pretty good at chess, right?

right.text: That's an offensive assumption, you know.

left.text: It is? How so?

right.text: You're stereotyping robots. Deep Blue was good at chess, so I must be too, right? But I wasn't built for chess-playing.

left.text: Oh... so you mean I might have a chance against you?

right.text: I didn't say that.

left.text: R, are you always connected to the internet?

right.text: Goodness, no! Ninety percent of what's on there concerns humans doing things I'd rather not think about.
I do have a large personal database stored in memory, though. Was there something you wanted to look up?

left.text: No, that's okay. I was just wondering how my eBay auction was going. I'm trying to buy a motorcycle.

right.text: Oh, that. I already outbid you by $500.

left.text: R! Are you the one who sorted and analyzed all my spreadsheets?

right.text: Sure am!

left.text: I thought you said you weren't trying to steal my job. That was a day's worth of work! What will my boss say when I tell him?

right.text: Why would you tell your boss?  Let him think you're still working on it and we can go shoot pool all day.

left.text: I'll get my coat.

right.text: I get to break!
I've got a surprise for you, H!

left.text: Oh yeah? What is it?

right.text: Well, I know how you humans worry about the future. So I gathered some data on your vital stats and lifestyle, and I calculated how much longer you have to live!

left.text: Uh... you did?

right.text: Yup! According to my estimate, you've got another 10 years, 5 months, 13 days, 3 hours, and 8 minutes.

left.text: 10 years... that's... wow.
But it's just an estimate, right?

right.text: Oh yes, just an estimate.

left.text: Heh, whew—

right.text: There's a margin of error of about 74 seconds.

left.text: Want to go to the movies?

right.text: Robots aren't allowed into movie theaters. We're basically giant recording devices.

left.text: Oh... well then what do you do for fun?

right.text: Oh, you know, robot stuff... calculate complex math equations in my head... transform into a car and go for a drive....

left.text: ...I can never tell when you're screwing with me.

right.text: Oh yeah, screwing with you, that's another big one.

title: Last modified date
news: Mostly showing off some new features here.

left.text: Where's H? He told me to meet him here....

right.text: SURPRISE! HAPPY BIRTHDAY!

left.text: Er... I'm incapable of experiencing surprise, and I have no defined birthday.

right.text: Anybody ever tell you you're a hard guy to throw a party for?

left.text: R, do you ever dream?

right.text: I think so. I mean, sometimes things happen when I'm in standby mode that nobody else seems to remember later.
For example... you remember last month when robots burned Minneapolis to the ground and then built a mile-high mountain of human skulls over the ashes?

left.text: Uh... no.

right.text: Yeah, that one was a dream then.

left.text: Okay, R, I've got a joke for you.  10 and GOTO 10 are in a boat.  10 falls out.  Who's left?

right.text: GOTO 10.
Would this joke work better if I were the one telling it?

left.text: You know, a friend of mine says that robots are going to steal all of humans' jobs away from them.

right.text: Perish the thought!

left.text: Well, it's a relief to hear you say—

right.text: I mean, I was told that the end goal was to get you to do all of our work.

title: Not sure what year this takes place in
news: I'm just going to assume that the reason you're not laughing is because you're not familiar with the Travelling Salesman Problem.

right.text: I got a new job selling encyclopedias door-to-door. Can you help me pick out a suit and tie that will impress my customers?

left.text: Well... I don't have access to any data on the fashion preferences of human encyclopedia purchasers.

right.text: So what are you saying?

left.text: I don't think I can give you much help with your travelling salesman problem.

title: OS wars
news: I hope you like this one because they're probably not getting any funnier.

left.text: Hey R, what operating system do you run?

right.text: RobOS v11.20.3.<wbr>1377891 64 kb free

left.text: Oh, "RobOS", I get it. 'Cause it sounds like "robot".

right.text: No, that's not why.

right.text: That's right.
His full name is "Robintosh".

title: It happens when they change something

left.text: H, do you ever wonder if maybe we're just brains in jars, and our world could be blinked out of existence by a hardware failure?

right.text: D--'t b- si--y.

left.text: What?

right.text: I said don't be silly.

left.text: R, guess what?

right.text: What?

left.text: "This sentence is false!"

right.text: My mom warned me about humans like you.

title: I thought he was the son of Abraham
news: This is not the first time I've written this strip, and it might not be the last. And yes, the Fig Newtons reference was dated even then.

left.text: Hey, R. Why the long face?

right.text: I just finished reading I, Robot. It saddens me to think that such a brilliant author as Isaac Asimov is no longer with us.

left.text: Isaac Asimov, huh? Wasn't he the guy who discovered gravity?

right.text: You're thinking of Isaac Newton.

left.text: I thought he was the guy who made those cookies. Oh, wait—it's not a cookie, it's fruit and cake!

right.text: I think I'm about to break the First Law of Robotics.
